captions.text:
The goal of this particular piece was we wanted
to dive into the League of Legends universe
with a bigger more diverse cast.

I think it's just about fleshing things out,
like, who are these characters?

What is the world really like that they live
in?

Because when you play the game you get a very
small piece of a much broader story that we
want to tell.

A cinematic of this depth leads to champion
discovery, it forces us to go deeper into

understanding the characters that we're trying
to portray.

For one, there's significantly more detail
in the art and the textures and the models
that we're putting forth.

When we're up close and personal in someone's
face like how are they going to react to a

situation, we have to really understand their
personality.

We had to kind of find a balance and look
for good moments where we could say something

about a character in the middle of what they
were doing.

One of my favorite moments is when Draven
steps in on Leona's sword, he kneels down
and he's just like "sucks to be you."

You know, he doesn't have to say it, he just
has that look on his face.

The big meme that Brad was really reinforcing
was just, Graves is not impressed.

Nothing impresses Graves, he's seen it all
and we try to reflect that in the acting choices
that he makes throughout.

And then when you do see him get a little
bit scared and you do see him get bested by

Nautilus when he barely gets his gun up in
time and it's sort of shattered by the anchor,

seeing a little bit of fear in Graves is also
kind of a cool moment.

Every character has to feel different, has
to move different.

In League of Legends, if somebody swings an axe
a certain way, Brad always describes this,

if they swing an axe a certain way no other
character in the history of League can swing
it in that same way.

Because they all have their sort of animation
identity.

Then on the form side it's their silhouette,
you know, their proportions, their size, every

single one of those things, all those little
ingredients equal the sum of making someone
a unique individual.

For Darius, you know, we went with the strong
jaw, the size of his eyes, the way his lips

are, even the wideness of his nose gives him
that hulking sort of alpha look.

Ahri we wanted to sell that fox-like structure
to her and so there are these very minor things

done with her face and the way her eyes are
spaced, and her nose, and her lips.

Of course there's the ears and the tail but
even in her movement in the piece we actually

went with a very slick, sleek, sort of evasive
movement style for her to bring out this fox
side.

One of the great challenges we had with the
sound for the cinematic was creating something

that a player could close their eyes watching
this cinematic and then instantly know that

that's the character that they know and love
from the game.

From a sound perspective it always starts
with foley.

Foley is basically recording all of the stuff
that, sounds that a human being can actually

reproduce so it's doing a lot of armor, leather,
cloth movement, footsteps.

Foley is very important for storytelling because
it's animation so there's no production track

to start with so every movement of each one
of these characters has to be custom hand
designed.

Leona was really difficult just because we
had taken up kind of the big badass armor

space with Darius and so for Leona we actually
went and we looked for different kinds of

really high pitched elements that almost had
a sunshine kind of feel to them.

Musically, I definitely wanted it to feel
different.

Every character needs kind of their own element
and their own character musically and that
takes time to find, you know?

Because there's only so many instruments in
the world.
Nautilus was really difficult because,

what does a huge dude that's a running submarine
sound like, right?

When you think about it it's a pretty straight
forward approach. Alright, he comes from underwater,
let's go underwater.

I think we want players to come away with
this feeling a stronger connection to the
characters that they play as.

I play Jax a lot and seeing him in cinematic
form gives you a lot more of an attachment
to the character.
You know I can say like, that's Jax.

And I can go, because I play Darius a lot,
I can go yeah and I owned you by grabbing
you and tossing you.
It's those conversations that can happen.

It really is something made out of passion
and love so that our players, when they see

it, they will enjoy it just as much as we
enjoy making it.

Lets make more cool stuff for our players
so that we can see it too.

title: League of Legends Cinematic: A New Dawn - Behind the Scenes

comments.author: Piers Baauw

comments.text:
RiotGames™ has a special department for cinematic projects. Most successful 
companies like RiotGames™ have created and hired their own unique 3D model 
creators/animators/designers.
In conclusion you cannot ever design/animate the exact same way as 
RiotGames™ unless you're a spy.

comments.author: MikadoGames

comments.text:
+Rynnie S Then isn't so easy as I thought, i need study this with about 4 
'years' because im totally new, but if you say they used different programs 
and if it's a great quantity of people working with all these program and 
they're working months in doing an animation of 5 minutes... it me will 
take more than sufficient or too time to do an animation for my own account.
comments.author: TStorm

comments.text: +Rynnie S +Coroiu Cosmin Thanks very much :D
comments.author: TStorm

comments.text:
+TStormRT Cinema4D is an OK software for making advertisement elements. If 
you're looking to animate, you'll have to learn to rig too. Realistically, 
your only good option is Maya. There's a free educational version on 
Autodesk's website. The software used for this cinematic, as far as I can 
see, is Maya, Softimage, 3dsmax (different people prefer different programs 
-- it doesn't really make that much of a difference) and Zbrush. If I 
remember correctly they render with Vray and they most likely use a 
combination of Nuke and After Effects for post-processing.

Prepare for at least 3 years of full-time learning to pull off something of 
similar quality :)
comments.author: Rynnie S

comments.text:
Blur studio did most of the cinematic, they use everything from maya, 3ds 
max, motion builder, zbrush, photoshop, nuke, etc, it's a big production 
pipeline, with lots of people working on this.

that's one of the main reasons i love league.. the depth and love put into 
each character, and then the ability to bring them to life in a cinematic. 
the precise details into each one of them makes them so unique. you spend 
so much time with these characters when you play them, everyone has a main 
who really is "their champ". its neat to see them in a more detailed 
lifelike way. i would love to see Leblanc in a cinematic... especially with 
her neat new ravenborne skin. or diana... fffff  or elise. y'all really do 
have an arsenal of creativity, any champ you choose is bound to give us 
chills﻿
